title: *Constitutional and Civil Rights Impact Litigation
description:
*Constitutional and Civil Rights Impact Litigation (20546). 2 units.This seminar will explore strategic and legal issues related to litigating social justice impact cases to advance the constitutional and civil rights of vulnerable communities. The course will cover an array of contemporary issues and is informed by the instructor’s three decades’ experience conducting class action and appellate civil rights litigation on behalf of immigrants and other plaintiffs as the director of the ACLU national Immigrants’ Rights Project. The course will not focus on immigration law and will cover a variety of issues, including through guest speakers. Among the areas we will examine are: selecting and using test cases; strategic pleading; class action problems and organizational plaintiffs; ethical issues and "cause" lawyering; the use of amicus briefs; suits for damages versus injunctive relief; standing and mootness; coalition litigation; attorneys’ fees and settlements; public advocacy and media; and using litigation to affect government agencies and legislation. The course may also provide students an opportunity to participate in strategy roundtables with leading practitioners. Classes will be rescheduled and may meet somewhat irregularly during the semester to accommodate speakers and other scheduling imperatives. Paper or similar project approved by the instructor required. Permission of the instructor required. Enrollment limited. L. Guttentag.

Course Selection Information: In addition to listing this seminar among permission-of-instructor selections, students should submit a statement of interest of no more than 300 words by June 26 at 4:30 p.m.

Note: Students must attend the first class meeting (or have prior permission from the instructor to be absent) in order to stay enrolled.
